St. Cloud Technical & Community College Named Best for Vets St. Cloud, Minn.‚ÄîSt. Cloud Technical & Community College has been named to the Military Times‚Äô 2023 Best for Vets: College list. Military Times Best for Vets: Colleges is the largest and most comprehensive annual ranking of schools for military service members and veterans. ‚ÄúSCTCC‚Äôs inclusion on the Military Times‚Äô list informs veterans that SCTCC is ensuring our servicemembers and their families feel welcome and have an easy transition to civilian life,‚Äù said Heidi Smith, advisor to the Student Veterans of America Club. ‚ÄúThe College has and will continue to support veterans and military members by offering resources, shared spaces, and personal assistance.‚Äù The Military Times survey is sent to colleges and universities across the nation asking about their programs for veterans. The results are then analyzed, along with public data about colleges and universities obtained from the Department of Education and Department of Veterans Affairs, and turned into an official ranking. The methodology for the rankings is based on quantitative data and includes student success metrics, admissions, resources, human resources, financials, and recordkeeping. In 2023, 325 higher education institutions made the list, which includes public, private, and for-profit universities and colleges at the four- and two-year levels. SCTCC is one of three Minnesota institutions that made the list and one of two Minnesota State colleges. The 2023 rankings can be found on the Best for Vets website. ‚ÄúOur comprehensive survey and thoughtful methodology make our rankings best in class‚Äù said Mike Gruss, editor-in-chief at Sightline Media Group, parent company of Military Times. SCTCC is regularly listed on the Best for Vets lists and offers supports and services specifically for military veterans and their families. Additionally, SCTCC is a Yellow Ribbon Company, which shows that key areas within a company structure create a network that proactively supports servicemembers and military families. About Military Times The Military Times is the trusted source for independent news and information for service members and their families. The military community relies on Air Force Times, Army Times, Marine Corps Times, and Navy Times for reporting on everything important to their lives, including branch-specific news, pay, benefits, finance, education, health care, recreational resources, retirement, promotions, product reviews, and entertainment. Military Times is owned by Sightline Media Group. To learn more, visit www.militarytimes.com.

Katie üåô Helbling and I are going to chatting about this soon... the idea of reinstating the draft is a solution in search of a problem. And, since Congress has neglected to fix the Selective Service system, it's a solution that already has issues to resolve before it could be workable. The idea of mandatory national service has merit, but only if it offers broader options beyond military service, e.g., Habitat for Humanity, Peace Corps, etc., and is tied to a post-9/11 GI Bill-type program that extends benefits to a broader array of service while allowing a greater range of options for utilization of those benefits. That kind of a program could be transformative for our country, for our society, and for future generations. But throwing around the idea of a draft is short-sighted and poorly conceived. Not that that slows anyone down.

What data is used to determine the best college for veterans? I mean that sincerely because I can‚Äôt seem to figure out these rankings. According to the 2024 U.S World News Report, the number 1 listed college for Veterans DOES NOT have the following: 1. A Veterans Resource Center 2. Priority Enrollment for GI Bill Users 3. Transfer of Military Credits It does have a 95% graduation rate, with just over 90 undergraduate veterans enrolled, 604 GI Bill User‚Äôs, and as of 2020, 2 TA users. It also does a TON of research and philanthropy benefiting veterans & military families within the state. Now this is a great school, and I‚Äôm sure the veterans enrolled have access to the resources they need for success. My point is - with such a small number of actual veterans attending and lack of basic resources that lower ranked schools have for veterans- why the number 1 spot? Are these rankings based on fundraising, research, and political visibility, or rankings based on resources available to #studentveterans ? I'd love to hear your thoughts. *Note: The number 1 ranking is a tie between 2 other schools, but listed alphabetically. All data presented on this post is based on first school listed. ** I am in no way saying these aren't deserving, reputable institutions- but curious about the criteria measured to be ranked #1 for veterans.
